summary: Living large and loving life, Po (Jack Black) realizes that he has a lot to learn if he's going to fulfill the next challenge from his beloved instructor (Dustin Hoffman). After reuniting with his long-lost father (Bryan Cranston), Po must transition from student to teacher and train a group of fun-loving, clumsy pandas to become martial-arts fighters. Together, the kung-fu brethren unite to take on the evil Kai (J.K. Simmons), a supernatural warrior who becomes stronger with each battle.

reviews.content: O tema musical do vilão foi realmente muito daora, e sem contar que o filme já começa com tudo, entra uma batalhar mais do que lendaria. Porém acho que o filme em comparação aos anteriores, perdeu um pouco a qualidade do roteiro, onde mestres treinados de alta qualidade perdessem de uma forma um tanto "ridicula", mas em si o filme é bom.
This movie is so visually beautiful and the story is amazing. Easily one of the best movies I've seen.

best one so far.

Kung Fu Panda 3 gave Poe god-like abilities and the power of an approaching storm but he lacks to calculated coldness of his character architype.

Pros:
+ Has probably my favorite action scenes in the franchise
+ The villain's theme kicks ass and I got pumped every time I heard it
+ Beautiful animation
+ Baby pandas are cute

Cons: 
- The character arcs were largely uninteresting, presenting conflicts that feel to generic and trite for a series that started out as interesting as it did
- The jokes, which are slightly better than in the previous movie, still suck
- The good stretch in the middle of just hanging out in the Panda village (while cute) did harm the pacing and make the movie feel about a half hour longer than it was

5.5/10

I enjoyed Kung Fu Panda 3 - it features impressive CGI, themes relating to personal identity and there were funny moments, as well as more general entertaining moments, a few thoughtful moments and the like. For just over an hour and a half, it kept me entertained, I didn't get bored and I enjoyed seeing how the hero, Po, dealt with the situation he was landed with, how he reacted to discovering new relatives. I won't say anymore so as not to spoil the film for you but if you enjoyed the previous 2 Kung Fu Panda films then I reckon you'll enjoy this too, so I'd recommend it on that basis.

Not as good as the first or second at all. Plot was too basic, had head scratcher moments (see below for more detail) and did not match with the message of "be yourself".

*Spoiler alert**
Problems with plot:
1.How did Oogway's brother-in-arms Kai become such an evil villain? You'd think that red flags would have come up earlier for Oogway if his soul brother was the "destroy the world" type. So bad character development there.
2. All the kungfu masters in the land couldn't defeat Kai and his jade zombies but a small village of overweight, untrained villager pandas could? Including children pandas and a ribbon dancer who took out two zombies by herself? Master Chicken and 3 other masters got their asses whooped even when they combined forces!
3. How did Po know doing the wu xi finger hold on HIMSELF would send Kai back to the spirit realm? And how did he know that Kai couldn't just pop back into the mortal realm like he did in the first place? If anything Kai has even more chi collected now than before...
Mano, tem o Pou. Cabo ai!

Sinceramente, achei um filme ok, nada demais. Na questão do Kung Fu o filme acerta em cheio, mas o que roda em volta disso não é lá essas coisas. Algumas piadas são legais, mas infelizmente diferente dos seus antecessores, este filme não acerta nas piadas que eram pra ser para um publico geral. Aqui eu sinto que as piadas são só para o publico infantil mesmo. Novamente falando, algumas são boas, mas no geral não são lá muito boas. O vilão, Kai, não é tão interessante a unica coisa boa mesmo é sua trilha sonora. Na real, é que Kung Fu Panda sempre acerta nas trilhas sonoras e aqui não foi diferente. No fim, é um filme que da pra se divertir com a família, uma animação muito bonita e bem feita e o filme mais infantil da saga do nossa amado Panda.
I had a super fun time watching it.

Una fiesta de emociones musica perfecta, banda sonora al compas, historia grandiosa, cierre perfecto, pero algo no anda bien aqui y es que en algunos momentos no se siente la tensión como en las anteriores otro creo que es el villano menos memorable pero con un origen que pudo ir mucho más alla de lo que fue.

Po become the master in Kung Fu Panda 3, an exciting fun-filled adventure. When an evil warlord returns from the spirit world, Po must master the art of chi in order to defeat him. Most of the original cast returns and are joined by J.K. Simmons and Kate Huds.The animation is really good, with a lot of different coloring and interesting character designs even the comedy delivers a lot of laughs. Even  though most of it is aimed at children.  Yet despite its flaws, Kung Fu Panda 3 is an entertaining and enjoyable family film.

Great feel good movie that is fun to watch for children and adults alike. Kung Fu Panda 3 takes the trilogy towards a completed journey of exploring the importance of finding one's self. Exploring how to be a panda is only a part of Po's journey to learning who he truly is.

This third Kung Fu Panda movie was great. Jack Black, Angelina Jolie, Dustin Hoffman, Bryan Cranston, J.K. Simmons, Seth Rogen, Jackie Chan, Lucy Liu, and the rest of the cast did a great job in this movie. The story of the movie was entertaining and humorous. It's about becoming what you always meant to be. If you haven't seen this movie yet, check it out sometime. It's a great movie for an entire family.

Regular película, sin dudas la mas floja de la trilogía por mucho, no se como bajaron tanto el nivel. Para empezar, el humor es muy absurdo y forzado, en todo momento tratan de meter algún chiste haciendo que algunas escenas no se tomen en serio, dejándolas completamente infantiles y nada emotivas. No me gusta para nada que haya una involución en los personajes, por ejemplo Po vuelve a ser el inexperto de la primera cinta, solo que acá es más tonto y menos consciente de lo que ocurre en la mayoría de los acontecimientos; esto mismo pasa con otros personajes secundarios. Es una lastima que Shifu y los 5 Furiosos acá solo están en segundo plano, no aportan prácticamente nada en casi toda la película, y sus participaciones son ligeramente reducidas, siendo opacadas principalmente por Po y toda la aldea de pandas, una manada de personajes que solo están ahí aportando chistes sin gracia. El villano no me gusto nada, su trama deja huecos argumentales y ni siquiera tiene conexión con el protagonista, simplemente Kai es malo y quiere matarlo, no hay una verdadera conexión, cosa que si lo hubo con Tai Lung y con Shen. Después, hay cosas sin sentido alguno, como que Po podía hacerse el skadoosh a él mismo, cosa de la que nunca se demostró o se habló de ello en la primera o en la segunda; además, los pandas son capaces de darle chi a Po por como se les dé la gana, como por ejemplo al decir bebe con rayas les funciona, cualquier cosa la verdad. En conclusión, es una lastima como arruinaron lo que podría haber sido una trilogía perfecta con esta película, tenia mucho potencial y presentaron una trama muy ilógica y conveniente, y con un humor tonto y forzado. La recomiendo solo porque es el final de la trilogía.
i actually change my name it was a good movie i think does movie is good the weakest but still fun 7/10.

King fu panda 3 has always been better than it deserves to be, and this one proves to be no exception, reaching its audience with a continuing important message of finding my yourself and helping others as you grow and mature.
This is an excellent movie. The end is beyond cool, Po becomes so stylish.
I absolutely love this movie franchise! I hope we get a fourth one

not as good as the other 2 but incredibly great

Kung Fu Panda 3 is another fresh entry in this franchise. It had a very important work to end this trilogy perfectly and it did. It is arguably the most ambitious film in the series and a lot emotions thrown into the mix. And the humor is great. Although only the animation of pandas isn't that much finished but if you have only this flaw in the movie then you are successful in entertaining an audience. Also, the climax is one of the best. So now, I can say confidently that kung fu panda is one of the most consistent franchises of all time.

Unlike The second movie this one doesn't manage to reinvent itself in a meaningful way. Instead, it takes the route of replicating the first movie's messages to a lesser effect. The result is somewhat convoluted and less satisfying. The humor is also dumber and a lot more hit-or-miss than the earlier installments. All in all, the film isn't bad but it's a far cry from its predecessors.

My issues with this movie comes down to one key issue: its relation to the first two movies in the trilogy.  This shows through in a number of ways: largely the story and the drastic change in tone.

The story of the first two movies has Po out of his depth, coming to terms with a facet of himself through great effort and struggle.  In the first, he must come to terms with the responsibility he always dreamed of having, and the consequences should he fail to live up to that responsibility.  He goes through a crucible, realizing that every single one of his heroes despises him, and what he represents, then realizing he is expected to defend the valley from the greatest threat it has ever faced.  In the second movie, Po must face the man who killed his parents and led a genocide of his people, orphaning him and making him the last of his species.  Lord Shen is certain that he killed every single panda.  Po must come to terms with his past, and in doing so saves all of China from a despot.  
The third movie starts by completely subverting the plot of the second.  The pandas survived!  The reason the second movie exists, and Po's struggle therein, is now far less meaningful.  And Po's struggle in the third movie is less interesting and less meaningful than those previous.  He's told he's now a teacher, and worries that he isn't able to do his job well.  The stakes are far lower, and the emotional impact is similarly reduced.  If he can't teach well, then his friends training will suffer until he figures it out.  Then, upon arriving in the Panda village, Po just... figures out how to teach.  He didn't go through anything in an attempt to figure out how to teach, he just magically got better.  
The other side of the story, in which Po finds his family while dealing with Kai, is similarly bland.  His father, who we've never met and have no reason to care about beyond a single line in the second movie and the expectation that 'if he's Po's father, then we have to care about him', is introduced and immediately we're struck with the expectation that the character deserves the audience's attention and emotional connection.  The writers didn't let Ping feel replaced, they didn't let Po wonder why he'd lived without his people for his entire life, and they expected an emotional connection to exist in a vacuum.  
As far as antagonists go, Tai Lung was amazing and Lord Shen impeccable.  Kai threatens far less than his predecessors: Tai Lung threatened the entire Valley, and beyond.  Shen threatened all of China.  Kai threatened a few dozen characters, less than 10 of which we actually know.  Kai doesn't connect to Po's inner struggle at all in the same way that Tai Lung and Shen did.  And Kai's attitude throughout is far less distinctive than his predecessors.  
The humor and campiness of this third installment were also grating, especially after the wonderful physical humor and genuinely intense mood that the first two movies attained at critical points.  Meanwhile, the final fights here are interspersed with random panda villagers doing one move, then celebrating, or Po just grandstanding, instead of genuinely reaching out to his enemies as he did in the first two movies.  That said, these are far more apparent than the issues above, which took me a while to put to words.  I'm far happier just watching the first two movies and considering that the end of the series.

I had to think really hard about my thoughts for this movie. I hold the Kung Fu Panda franchise very close to my heart. I have invested a lot of my time in not just the movies, but as well as the side series. Overall, I think this is a great movie, it just left me feeling very underwhelmed. It still has all of the great elements from the first two films. The animation, the action, and the deep themes are all present in the third installment of this franchise. The new style of Kung Fu that is introduced, chi, was a pretty good addition. Also, I liked how they were able to reintroduce Oogway into the storyline. And of course...you have Po, who is still the lovable and funny lead protagonist we all love. All of these aspects are the reason why I love this franchise so much. However, I still feel that there was a lot of missed potential here and somethings that simply weren't going to work for me. Kai as the villain was fine for me, but he felt much more generic compared to the villains from the previous films. I didn't like how Shifu and the Furious Five were off in the distance for this film (though their minimal amount of screen time is pretty awesome). But my biggest issue with the film is the other pandas (more specifically Li (Po's father) and Mei Mei). The other pandas make the film feel a lot more childish, and I didn't find any of their interactions with Po to be that funny. This was something I expected though, so I wasn't as bothered at that. After, the primary audience for most of the DreamWorks films is younger children. But there were two new characters that I believe were the epitome of wasted potential. First of all their is Po's biological father Li. Considering how the two of them reuniting was the main plot of the story, it seemed like a great continuation of the storyline. But most of their interactions with each other are meant to be for jokes, and when the creators tried to make some emotional moments with them, it felt sort of disingenuine. And then you've got Mei Mei. This flirtatious Panda was the most disappointing part of this film for me because I had such high hopes for her. Giving Po a girlfriend would have been a genius move on their part as it could really help shape his arc as the Dragon Warrior. Her one good interaction with Po is their first one, where she's flirting with Po, but making it seem like he flirting with her. And that's it. That is literally all that she does. She learns how to use nunchucks...and...um...she...uh...yeah that's about it. It might seem like I am being hard on this movie and I am. But it is simply because I know the potential that these movies have. That with another sequel in the works, DreamWorks could give us a franchise that could surpass How to Train Your Dragon. They didn't utilize certain plot points that would have made this movie so much better.  If this were the last movie, I definitely would have disliked it much more, but maybe they can make amends in future installments. As nitpicky as I am, I think that this still a great family film that I recommend. Just make sure you watch the first two movies first.
Amazing Must Watch This!

What an absolutely gorgeous and touching story. 
I didn't notice in the past films, but the colors  are simply so freaking amazing in this film. Just feels so perfect. Despite the fact that I already know the story, it still touched me deeply. The ideas behind everything is incredibly simple, yet the simplicity is able to create deeply touching moments. The story moves pretty fast, usual for a 1h30 min film, nothing is really time filler. Will watch again in the future, no doubt.

It has stellar animation, well-developed characters, and a story that expertly mixes comedy, drama and action, bringing the trilogy to an imperfect but satisfying conclusion.
Not as good as the first two Kung Fu Panda movies, but still a great addition to the franchise. It's funny, emotional and filled with fun action. Definitely worth seeing.

A really good ending to a really good series. The cast is good and some of the ideas they play with are the best in the trilogy. The pacing felt off at times and some of the character actions I didn’t agree with.
Kung Fu Panda 3 has nore humor than previous entries, but it's villain and premise are underdeveloped.

This is definitely the weakest out of the trilogy. It was another great character study, and another fun sequel to my favorite DreamWorks series. The villain, while not nearly as interesting as the predecessors, still has a fun storyline throughout the whole movie. They also managed to expand some themes from the first two films. A pretty good film. I‘d recommend it.

Kung fu panda 3 was a big dissapointment to me, I really like the first and seciond movie, this movie for my is one of the most forgetable movie of DreamWorks,(yes I will remember the boss baby because hiw awful it was) I think this movie is still a good movie just not as epic at the first one or the second one, the best five furious best dialogue were when they were statues, sorry everyone I'm just to dissapointed, I kind of like Po's dad, I mean Bryan Cranston is great, I really like how Po defeats Kai I think that was smart but how does he return of dead for me is bad writing that is just bad, well then I will Give kung fu panda 3 a 7 out of 10

But Jesus Christ this was nothing but all comedy, and A disappointment for me to experience. While decent, this movie really didn't need to be made. It has a central topic of fatherhood which isn't quite as well executed as it could've been. Most of the humor aims to center around the natural humor in fat pandas. This humor feels like the directors changed their target audience to be younger and also to appeal more to Happy Meal toys. They definitely ran out of interesting villains and put in an underdeveloped guy who likes green. I want to say that fighting his own team is well utilized as a battle mechanic here but it honestly doesn't make for exciting action. Decent movie in quality but one that feels pointless.

This film, in my honest opinion, is the ideal movie to watch on Father's Day and for good reason. It not only paints blood fathers in a good light, something I wish I could really relate to on a personal level, but adopted fathers in a good light, both at the same time, something I never thought I'd see especially from Dreamworks.

The story is that Po enters the long hidden panda village and re-unites with his biological father and the other pandas, but problems arise when a villainous spirit warrior, named Kai, returns to the living realm and proceeds to steal chi from the kung fu masters. Along the way Po continues to bond with his father and the other pandas within the village. All the while secrets are unfortunately discovered and his friends, the furious five, have had their chi taken as well. To prevent Kai from taking chi from all other kung fu masters and pandas, Po forms the army of pandas, alongside Tigress and his adoptive father, to battle Kai's jade minions and Po must become a master of chi to defeat him and save those of the living realm.

This was a film I was absolutely wanting for the longest time after the cliffhanger ending of Kung Fu Panda 2 which is still my personal favorite of the three movies, but this one is still pretty good. Like I mentioned earlier, this is one of the few movies I've seen that actually manages to paint a mostly positive and relatable relationship between not just Po and his two different dads, but the dads actually coming to an understanding and accepting each other both as part of Po's life. Try to think of any other movie and/or show that can not only do that, but do it in a way that's funny, charming, and respectable. This is also one of the few animated films I've seen that actually does a liar revealed that doesn't feel overly cliched and drawn out, if anything else, not only was I actually was kind of surprised when it happened the first time I saw the movie, but you completely understand the reasoning behind it and the reasoning behind the affect it has when it does happen. I won't give away what it is specifically for those who haven't seen it, but let's just say, it was surprisingly well done.

As for the other things, the animation is still really gorgeous. The action, while not as fast and impressive as the last two, is more portraid in a larger spectacle especially in the spirit realm which feels a lot like a beautiful chinese painting brought to life in the best of ways. The blend of comedy and drama from the previous two return and are, for the most part, just as well done here. The only two problems I have with this film is that the formula of these movies does start to really become aparent in this and, while I do like this movie a lot, I'd be lying if I said I didn't feel the basic formula in this from time to time. And the villain, while he does get some good laughs and still does have a decent backstory, just isn't nearly as memorable as the villain in the last film despite both having a great design and having J.K Simmons hamming it up at times.

Overall, while the film is far from perfect, if you want the best kind of movie to make you and your dad feel special this father's day, this is the perfect film to do that with.
Man a good animated movie

Lacking what the first two had. The first one was fresh and was a smart and funny take on a concept that belongs in a 70's cartoon but works and the second one took things further with a darker storyline. Kung Fu Panda 3 isn't as well-executed as the other two, it's humor falls flat this time, it feels like as a downgrade and Po has lost his maturity of the second one. This isn't a bad movie, it still has heart, good animation and a really good score, just a disappointment when looking back at the other two. If you're just as disappointed in this DreamWorks threequel like I was, go watch HTTYD 3 instead.
One of my favorite animation trilogy. The story, color script, and characters are just an absolutely gem.

The animation is better, but it doesn't hold a candle to the other two. There's still great comedy and solid messages that the franchise is known for. However, the execution seemed rushed. We have a villain that isn't really memorable or has logical reasoning. The goofy environment doesn't blend well when it needs to be serious. Also, the ending is pretty lame too. You probably will enjoy it, but its not as amazing in comparison to the first two installments or other animated films and sequels.

Everything this had to offer it hit out of park. This movie made it self better than the first. This movie also made up for the awful Kung Fu Panda 2. Also thi movie came with the best badass in this franchise. The master Sifu is probably the one best deaths in the series.

Kung Fu Panda 3 may not be the as original as the first or as stylistic as the second, but it is definitely the most touching and heartfelt of the three. Surprisingly enough, Kung Fu Panda 3 matches the original in ways that make it feel like a wholly different beast of a film, improving on the visual foundations of its predecessors. The score is powerful but more subtle, fitting the more subdued and emotional tone of the film. Jennifer Yuh improved on her abilities, making a threequel that both matches and at times surpasses the first film.
The third installment still doesn't justify the decision to move past the original. Standard animation entertainment.
Continuing the tradition of beautiful animation, humor, heart, and action, Kung Fu Panda makes something truly unique in Hollywood, an enjoyable beginning to end trilogy the whole family can enjoy.
had nothing to do with kung fu, the other ones were way better

Kung Fu Pnada 3 is in total, a massive let down. From the failure to fulfill the great posability left after the amazing kun fu panda 2, in regards to Po's dad and the accompanying panda village, it all totally falls on its face as the characters are flat and hold little emtional connection to the world we have grown to love over the last two films. The real failing however being the villain: Kai, as he is called is a complet disappointment from start to finish, which is a total shame coming off the bat of two amazing villains prior. Kai's "motivation", if you want to describe it as that, is just a boring excuse. I'm annoyed by the fact this film has found moderate critical success, I love the kun fu panda series and everything that has come with it, however this film is just not good, and my hope is that when a fourth is made (if it ever will) it will not make the same mistakes, and carry on its prior amazing character development of Po.
An adequate finale to the Kung Fu Panda trilogy. The lesson here is not to take things too seriously. Great cinematology and choreography once again define the film's stellar visuals.
In my opinion the second one was better however this movie is not a disappointment either and I think everyone that chooses to watch it will love it

Its philosophically inspired messages still convey a lot of inspiring vigor, but "Kung Fu Panda 3" goes beyond a silly and casual humor that attracts not just the lucky ones and the family, it has a great saga-end scent with an engaging and heartwarming story Beat the boredom thanks to its great action scenes even more impressive!
Weakest one of the trilogy, but it's still really good.

I dont know how no one talks about the terrible pace of the humor on this movie, almost everything feels forced and too electric, very tiring. This movie had a story with great potential, but the execution was pretty bad. I'll give more stars to the very good animation and music of course.
Po encuentra a sus parientes, pero se da cuenta que la familia es mucha más que solo la relación biológica, divertida como suele ser y con buenos mensajes para los niños y los no tan niños también.

The Kung Fu Panda saga grows in animation quality with the third installment, but sadly, that's about it. I wanted to like it more than I did, but 3 is a little too cheesy, cliché, predictable, and makes too little sense to be as good as the first two. The story is weaker, and some of the humor is off. The villain, Kai, is okay, but has neither the energy of Tai Lung nor the creepiness of Shen that made them such great characters. Kung Fu Panda 3 isn't a terrible movie, but it was a little disappointing.

It's almost impressive to drag out a series like this without getting too stupid or outdated, but this series manage it in a way. It's not smart or amazing or anything, but it's cheap fun with characters that kids dig. Childish and stressfilled with loads of energy and action among the humor that mostly hits - at least for it's target group.

Fantasyfilled, typical and easy to forget. It needs a mention that I was working on other things while this film was on, so I never put both my eyes to this film for more than thirty minutes.

4 out of 10 nunchucks.

The last film of the trilogy, "Kung Fu Panda 3 " is a more mature and different version of the concept of animation of Dream works. The film focuses on few scenarios, but explores points not yet seen in the trilogy. Limited, but satisfactory.

The animation is gorgeous and the action is fun, as before. But neither the plot nor the jokes are as on point as in the first two films. The panda village is adorable of course, so kids will hardly notice. They will have difficulties with the very spiritual finale, I imagine.
Not as good as 2 (in my opinion), but still really good but much slower and not as much of the villain as I would’ve liked but still amazing and gorgeous animation
An enjoyable reboot that focuses more on comedy than action.
This was a Nice movie to watch i watch about 2 times

The best word to describe this move is "speed". You don't have a chance to get bored. Always something is happening at the screen but it doesn't mean the pace of the movie is all over the place. No, you get a few moments to rest and, for me, they gave you as many of them as you could need. And finally they got the ending right. No Ex machina this time

Kung fu panda 3 is yet another great addition in the trilogy. I would rate Kung fu panda three above the second film but still not as good as the original. The film is fast paced with good animation, likable characters, and good voice acting. The film is not going to blow anybody away it's just a good addition to the previous films. If you're happy with that you would enjoy this.

After I watched Kung Fu Panda 3, it made me so happy that I can start laughing again. Po finally knows who he is, he meets his father, Li Shan and the funny thing is that Mr Ping is so jealous, I couldn't stop laughing. And seeing Oogway in the Spirit Realm in the third movie just made me feel so happy. The part that I saw that made my jaw dropped is when I saw the new secret panda village and that just made my mind blew up. I'm giving it 5 stars because this movie is so much better than Kung Fu Panda 2
It just undoes everything the first two movies stood for.

Kung Fu Panda 3 is just like it's oldest brother, the first movie.  Filled with humor, fast paced, awesome characters, awesome animation, and just everything you can ask for in a Kung Fu Panda movie. The second movie is pretty good an everything, but didn't seem to have everything that made the first movie such a blast. Kung Fu Panda 3 on the other hand, like I said, has everything that made the first movie awesome. Tai Lung and Shen were great villains, but Kai just might actually take the cake and be the best one out of the three. He's more threatening than the other two, more cocky, and has several other qualities that make him a better villain than Tai Lung and Shen. Another thing that the third installment does very good is borrowing elements from the second movie. Kung Fu Panda 2, while very funny, had some pretty sad and emotional scenes, and Kung Fu Panda 3 is no stranger to that. I find that to be a very interesting touch, and was quite surprised that it did this. Overall, this is another installment to this awesome franchise that nobody should miss out on. 9 out of 10. I may find the first movie to be a bit better than this one, but this is a movie that no fan of the franchise should go without. Kids and adults will indeed both be entertained from start to finish with this great movie.

Kung Fu Panda 3 meets the minimum requirements in what fans of the first two films would expect: jokes about weight, Po's still struggling with handling Kung Fu (even though he became the "dragon warrior" at the end of the first film) and questions of how to determine what true family is. Sadly, the film itself lazily meets these expectations without providing much else for its fan base.

We start with an uninteresting villain played by J.K. Simmons. He is an associate of Master Oogway, and that is how he is known (this joke gets really old really fast within the film itself). He manages to escape the spirit realm (this universe's equivalent of the afterlife) and is determined to take over the spirits of kung fu masters because.... well who cares? The film simply establishes he is a bad guy who wants revenge and to have control over the real world - you know, your typical one-dimensional children's movie villain.

Po's father, played by Bryan Cranston, finds him at the start of the film, which is really convenient because pandas are supposed to know about something called "chi" which is what the villain is after. Pandas were known to heal Oogway with this power in the past, and it is of course the only way to stop Simmons' character. This subplot eventually clears up what we did not know about the pandas in this universe, and of course the film goes to great lengths to make comedy out of how lazy pandas turn out to be.

The jokes used in this film are just rehashed jokes from the first two films, not providing great comedy as its predecessors since it proves to be unoriginal. Kung Fu Panda 3 is still enjoyable, but its strength lies on the theme of questionable identity posed by the two competing fathers of the film: Mr. Ping and Li. This is only touched on a few times throughout the film, but when it is touched on it brings up interesting questions about whether Po would need nature or nurture: that is, does he need his biological father or the one who raised him. These moments are the only ones of great intrigue within the film.

There is also a return to a cop-out fighting technique from the first film that makes the conflict of the story less difficult for Po to get through. While the film has the same spirit of its predecessors, Kung Fu Panda 3 is not a very fun film, but it is not terrible. In  the Chinese Spirit Realm, Grand Master Oogway (Randall Duk Kim) fights against the spirit warrior and collector Kai (J. K. Simmons) and has his chi stolen, but not before he warns Kai that Po (Jack Black), the Dragon Warrior, will stop him. Kai disregards this and returns to the mortal world. Meanwhile, Master Shifu (Dustin Hoffman) announces his retirement and passes the role of teacher to Po. He discovers that teaching kung fu is hard, as the Furious Five members Tigress (Angelina Jolie), Crane (David Cross), Mantis (Seth Rogen), Viper (Lucy Liu), and Monkey (Jackie Chan) are injured as a result. Po is demoralized as a teacher, but is advised by Master Shifu to be himself.

Po heads home to his adoptive father Mr. Ping (James Hong) at his noodle shop where a panda named Li Shan (Bryan Cranston) breaks Po's dumpling-eating record. They both soon learn that Li is Po's biological father and they bond with each other much to Ping's jealousy. After introducing Li to Shifu and his friends, the Valley of Peace is suddenly attacked by past Kung Fu Masters turned into jade statues under the control of Kai. The team then learn through research that Kai was Grand Master Oogway's old friend who fought with him long ago, but was banished to the spirit realm for 500 years when he grew thirsty for the power of chi. Kai can only be defeated by a master of true chi, which they discover was an innate ability of the panda colonies. Po, at Li's suggestion, along with Mr. Ping, travels to the secret village where the pandas hide while Shifu and the Furious Five stay behind to investigate Kai's movements and defend the Palace. Although Po is eager to learn chi, he first learns the life of a panda in the village, which he feels grateful to be a part of.

After learning that all the Kung Fu masters are missing, Master Shifu sends Crane and Mantis to find them. Crane and Mantis join with other Kung Fu masters to confront Kai, but they all have their chi stolen. Kai then arrives at the Jade Palace and destroys it, then takes everybody's chi while Tigress escaped to find Po and warns him of the upcoming danger. Afraid, Li and the pandas prepare to run away. When Po demands that his father teaches him chi, he reveals that they had all forgotten chi, and he only wanted to save Po from Kai's wrath. Hurt over his father's misdirection, Po isolates himself and trains vigorously to confront Kai. Mr. Ping then comforts Li and admits he was initially worried Po would be taken away from him, but came to realize that Li being a part of Po's life simply added to his happiness, and that they should stay by Po's side as family.

Tigress confronts Po and tells him that he cannot defeat Kai without continuing to discover the secret of chi, during which Po confesses that the experience has him once more doubting his potential. Li and the villagers, having decided to stay, ask Po to train them so they can fight back. Po agrees and teaches them using their everyday activities as their assets and begins their plan to save their village. Kai arrives and sends his minions to capture Po, but they are held off by the pandas and Tigress, distracting Kai. The plan works, but ultimately fails when Po tries to use the Wuxi Finger hold on Kai, who reveals that it won't work on spirits. Kai gains the upper hand in their fight, but in a last-ditch effort, Po uses the Wuxi Finger Hold on himself while grabbing onto Kai, sending them both to the spirit realm. They fight again, but Kai defeats Po and prepares to steal his chi. Using what they learned from Po and about who they are, Li, Tigress, Mr. Ping and the pandas are able to use their chi to save him. Po, with the chi flow, suddenly generates a golden dragon-shaped avatar around him and destroys Kai by overloading him with his chi, freeing all of the Kung Fu masters in the process.

In an ethereal golden pond, Grand Master Oogway appears to Po, and informs him his journey has come full circle, revealing his role by selecting Po as Dragon Warrior is also because of his descent from the ancient pandas, and his embodiment of the yin-yang. He also reveals his role in alerting Li of Po's survival, and expresses his happiness to Po about how much he has grown. By choice, Po wields a mystic green staff bestowed by Oogway to return to the mortal world. Everyone returns to the Jade Palace, where Po proudly gazes upon his family, friends, and legacy in the spot where his journey began.
Kung Fu Panda 3: Another round up of gorgeous animation, action and storytelling. Kung Fu Panda 3 is a rare second animated seqeul that really works.
Slow to get into but once it picks up it's a noodle bowl full of Awesome!
Delightfully hilarious, Kung fu Panda 3 is the greatest film in the series.
Super cute and funny! The baby panda's are so cute and the end fight is super pretty and fun!

Although you can't help but feel like you've seen a lot of what's been done here in the last couple of films, it's amazing that this franchise is still finding interesting ways to re-tell the same story whilst introducing just enough new elements each time to make it something worth watching. 'Kung Fu Panda 3' is full of big visuals and heart-warming moments, and whilst it was nice to see the character development, it's just a shame that it came at the expense of the action which is somewhat disappointing considering the name of the franchise. Nevertheless, it is still a satisfying watch and should be an entertaining bit of fun for the whole family.

This entry to the series is a lot like the second, a truly beautiful and solid addition to the series, but is a tad bit under the quality of the original.  Still, the animation in this is truly something to behold.  If you liked the first two, I am sure you will find this one amusing as well.

While it doesn't measure up to the original, Kung Fu Panda 3 is fun for the whole family. Jack Black saves the film with his fun and fresh character voice work, but it felt as though the film makers were grasping at straws with the villain this time.
More kinda like the original, this sequel improves the story of Po and manages to make me apreciate very much this movie. The animation is better than ever, and the performances still good.

Story: 7/10

Animation: 10/10

Characters: 7/10

Overall Score: 8/10
I love this franchise, and this ends a perfect trilogy greatly.

Not quite as engaging as 2, but a fantastic finale to this legendary series.
